questions.question_text:
You need to identify street names based on street signs in photographs.

Which type of computer vision should you use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct.
Images -> Object Detection (Where is the object) -> Image Classification (Get label) -> OCR (Identify the name of place)

Selected Answer: B
Identify street name -> OCR

Selected Answer: A
To identify street signs you should use object detection. OCR is the second step.

To identify street names based on street signs in photographs, you should use optical character recognition (OCR). OCR technology enables computers to recognize and extract text from images, making it suitable for reading and interpreting text on street signs.
according to copilot answer is ocr

Selected Answer: B
answer is B, needs to extract text from signs

comments.content: Sorry I meant OCR - B is correct answer

discussion.content: Key word is Street Names so it is Image Classifications
Answer is A

comments.content: Its specifically states Street Names = text, so answer is B.

discussion.content: Most people have voted for OCR, but the signs are not always text.

Selected Answer: B
B. optical character recognition (OCR)

OCR is specifically designed to identify and read printed or handwritten text within images, which is necessary for extracting street names from photographs of street signs.
Incorrect Options:

A. Object detection: While this could identify the presence of a street sign in an image, it wouldn't read the text on the sign.
C. Image classification: This would categorize the image but not provide the detailed text information from the street signs.
D. Facial recognition: This is used for identifying and verifying individuals from images or video frames, not for text extraction.

Selected Answer: B
Reading text from images is OCR

Selected Answer: B
OCR - to read the text from the signs. Don't need object detection for this.
too many wrong answers for an AI-900 test preparation, like this one

Selected Answer: B
Answer B - OCR

Selected Answer: B
it's an OCR problem

Selected Answer: B
B. optical character recognition (OCR)

To identify street names based on street signs in photographs, you should use **optical character recognition (OCR)**. OCR technology is designed to recognize and extract text from images, making it the most appropriate choice for extracting text content from street signs. Options A, C, and D are not specifically designed for text extraction and analysis but rather for object recognition, image classification, and facial recognition, respectively.
B-OCR, because you are extracting test from images by identifying the characters.

Selected Answer: B
Ocr , b

Selected Answer: B
Checked with ChatGPT, Google Bard and Bing. They all agreed on OCR. Voting for OCR myself.
Shouldn't this be OCR?
Should be B. OCR.

discussion.content:
Image classification -> Generate captions for images.
Object detection -> Locate vehicles in images.
Optical character recognition (OCR) -> Extract movie title names from movie poster images.
OCR, OCR, Object Detection respectively, are the correct answers

Wrong answer.
Computer vision or NLP can generate captions for images. Image classification and Object detection are NOT able to generate captions.

The correct answer should be Image Captioning: This task generates descriptive sentences about the content of an image. It involves understanding the scene and creating a natural language description.

comments.content:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/computer-vision/concept-describing-images 
First one should be image analysis (image descriptions)

discussion.content: Image classification is NOT CORRECT
Answer is correct.

OCR, OCR, Objection Detection
For the first one, "Which of the following generates captions for images", none of the answers provided work unless there is text of some sort in the image. Image classification would categorize the entire image into a class / label. The only vaguely viable answer for the first one is OCR.
i will vote for object detection, OCR, object detection

ocr
OCR
Object detection

Answer for 1 is:
Object detection
Image classification typically involves assigning a label or category to an entire image, while optical character recognition (OCR) is focused on identifying and recognizing text within images. On the other hand, object detection involves identifying and locating objects within an image, and this task is often extended to generate captions that describe the detected objects and their spatial relationships in the scene.

The Real Answer should be: Image Analysis, OCR, Object Detection. 
The question choices are incorrect, as Image Classification is not the same as Image Analysis service.
Sorry Object Detection, OCR, Object detection are correct

choices.A: AI enrichment for Azure Search capabilities

questions.question_text:
You have a bot that identifies the brand names of products in images of supermarket shelves.

Which service does the bot use?

discussion.content:
Can't delete my previous comment. I guess I was wrong. The correct answer should be B.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/computer-vision/concept-brand-detection

comments.content:
I agree, B is correct answer.

Reasoning:
in the documentation linked by Freelf it states the below.

'The built-in logo database covers popular brands in consumer electronics, clothing, and more. If you find that the Vision service doesn't detect the brand you're looking for, you could also try creating and training your own logo detector using the Custom Vision service.'

Built in would refer to Computer Vision. you could also achieve this with Custom Vision but for the context of this question it does not mention any requirement to make a custom model, so you would not over engineer this. 

B is correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct answer. Models for Computer vision are trained by Microsoft.

Selected Answer: B
I'm choosing B based on comments and posing this question to AI search. Azure Computer Vision is the primary Azure AI service you'd likely use to identify brand names in images. It offers robust image analysis capabilities, including object detection and recognition.

Selected Answer: B
Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities

Azure's Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities include a feature called Brand Detection that can recognize popular brands within images. This pre-built functionality allows the bot to detect and identify brand logos and names without the need for custom model training.

Selected Answer: C
Custom Vision is a part of Azure’s Cognitive Services that allows you to build and refine your own custom image classification models. It can be trained to recognize various visual elements, including brand logos or specific products on supermarket shelves. While Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities can analyze and describe an image with tags, it’s not specifically designed for custom tasks like identifying specific brand names in images.

Selected Answer: C
Supermarkets have tens of thousands, if not hundred, of products. I believe Microsoft can identify big brands, like Tesla, Coca Cola, etc. They might have imported thousands of logos, but I don't think they can cover everything in a supermarket.

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B, Computer Vision. 

Brand detection is a specialized mode of object detection that uses a database of thousands of global logos to identify commercial brands in images or video. You can use this feature, for example, to discover which brands are most popular on social media or most prevalent in media product placement.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/computer-vision/concept-brand-detection

Selected Answer: B
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/computer-vision/concept-brand-detection

comments.content: Question is about brands, not custom entities. Correct answer is B.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Computer Vision does not have the capabilities to recognize custom entities. C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
Custom Vision allows you to train a model to recognize specific brands and objects within images, which is ideal for identifying and classifying various product brands on supermarket shelves.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
C is the Correct one

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

comments.content: In fact Computer Vision is trained to recognise thousands of brands present across the globe.
But in combination with the classification it does not make sense. So it must be B or the question is simply wrong...

discussion.content: It should be Custom Vision. Computer Vision can't be trained for all the brands in the world (in multiple countries and regions).

Selected Answer: B
For a bot that identifies brand names of products in images of supermarket shelves, the service used is:

B. Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities

Computer Vision can analyze images to detect and identify objects and text, making it ideal for recognizing brand names in images.
Incorrect Options:

A. AI enrichment for Azure Search capabilities: This is more for enhancing search capabilities with AI, not specifically for image analysis.
C. Custom Vision Image Classification capabilities: While it can classify images, Custom Vision requires specific training for each brand, which might not be practical for a wide range of supermarket products.
D. Language Understanding capabilities: This service is used for understanding spoken or written language, not for image analysis.

Selected Answer: B
It feels like it should be OCR but the closest match appears to be Image analysis it seems

Actually, the real service to be used in this context is OCR, if we assume that the brand name (and not just the logos) are visible on the packages. Training a custom Computer Vision model for this task is a bit of an overkill.

Selected Answer: B
This is Image Analysis and not Image Classification.

Selected Answer: B
ChatGPT

Selected Answer: B
Answer B. Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities.
Computer Vision is the domain of AI and machine learning that focuses on understanding and analyzing images and video content, making it well-suited for tasks like identifying brand names within images.

Selected Answer: C
Custom Vision Image Classification capabilities: This allows users to train a custom model on their own data. Given the specificity of identifying brand names on supermarket shelves, a custom-trained model would be ideal. With Custom Vision, you can label images of different brands and then use this model to classify new images based on those labels.

Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities: The generic Computer Vision service from Azure provides analysis of visual features in images, but for specific tasks like identifying brand names, Custom Vision would be more appropriate because it can be trained on specific datasets.
too many wrong answers for an AI-900 test preparation, like this one.

Selected Answer: B
Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities to identify the brand names of products in images of supermarket shelves . Therefore, the correct answer to your question is B.

Selected Answer: B
it's an object detection not classification problem

Selected Answer: C
The bot that identifies the brand names of products in images of supermarket shelves uses:

C. Custom Vision Image Classification capabilities

Custom Vision is designed for creating custom image classification models, making it suitable for the task of recognizing and classifying brand names of products in images. This service allows you to train models with your specific image data and categories. Options A, B, and D are not specifically designed for this image classification task and serve different purposes: Azure Search capabilities (A), Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities (B), and Language Understanding capabilities (D) have different primary applications.

B. Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities

To identify brand names of products in images, the bot would use the Computer Vision Image Analysis capabilities, which can recognize and extract information from images. AI enrichment for Azure Search, Custom Vision Image Classification, and Language Understanding capabilities are not typically used for this specific task.

Selected Answer: B
Agree on B. The question doesnt mention "Custom" brand names and The Computer Vision Image Analysis service is already trained to recognize a wide variety of visual features from images, including specific brands or objects. Voting for B myself
Should be B. Image Analysis.

Correct Answer is B: Language 

LUIS stands for Language Understanding Intelligent Service. It's a cloud-based artificial intelligence (AI) service from Microsoft Azure that helps developers build applications with natural language processing (NLP) capabilities.
Extracts meaning from text: LUIS analyzes user queries or conversational phrases and extracts the intent (what the user is trying to do) and entities (specific details) from the text.
q109 doubles

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
For developing a chatbot in Azure and determining a user's intent, you should use:

B. Language

Azure Language Service (formerly known as Text Analytics) includes features for understanding user intent from text inputs, making it suitable for chatbots.
Incorrect Options:

A. Translator: Used for language translation, not for intent recognition.
C. Azure Cognitive Search: Primarily used for search capabilities within large datasets, not for interpreting user intent.
D. Speech: Focused on converting speech to text and vice versa, not directly on understanding intent.

Selected Answer: B
LUIS, so language

Selected Answer: B
it is Language Understanding (LUIS)

questions.question_text:
You are developing a chatbot solution in Azure.

Which service should you use to determine a user’s intent?

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Knowledge mining -
You can use Azure Cognitive Search's knowledge mining results and populate your knowledge base of your chatbot.

Box 2: Computer vision -
Box 3: Natural language processing
Natural language processing (NLP) is used for tasks such as sentiment analysis.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/data-guide/technology-choices/natural-language-processing

I think it should be NLP, CV, NLP

Knowledge Mining
Data Extraction: Knowledge mining involves extracting useful information from large datasets. While it can be used to build a knowledge base for the chatbot, it is not the primary technology enabling the chatbot to interact with users.
Supporting Role: Knowledge mining can support the chatbot by providing a rich database of information from which the chatbot can pull answers. However, the actual interaction and understanding of user queries are driven by NLP.
In summary, while knowledge mining can enhance the chatbot’s database, NLP is the core technology
NLP-CV-NLP

The answer should be: NLP-CV-NLP
Here's the statement from NLP module:
"In the following example, a chat bot uses natural language and provides options to a customer to best handle their query."
Reference: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/build-faq-chatbot-qna-maker-azure-bot-service/2-understand-question-answering?ns-enrollment-type=learningpath&ns-enrollment-id=learn.wwl.explore-natural-language-processing

Answer: NLM, CV, NLM

I understand the chatbot question is debatable.

A chatbot would use NLM to process and answer user questions about refunds and exchanges. It involves analyzing the text, finding the intent, and creating a response that is correct and related to the question. It would use Knowledge Mining to look through documents, FAQs, and other data sources to find answers to user questions. A possible solution for a chatbot to handle refunds and exchanges would combine both:
• NLP to communicate with the user and comprehend their queries
• Knowledge Mining to access the relevant information from the company’s rules and data sources to provide correct responses

However, if I had to choose one, NLM would typically be the preferable option for several reasons that include:
• Immediate Engagement
• Customer Satisfaction
• Instant Processing
• Flexibility
It should be Natural Language Processing
